Answer.ValidTrueComment:
STIG Requirement: Non-privileged user sessions must time out after 15 minutes of inactivity (APSC-DV-000070).
Xen Orchestra does not natively expose a configurable idle session timeout in config.toml or via environment variable. The check searched config.toml, process environment, and XO source for sessionTimeout, idleTimeout, or token expiration settings. No qualifying 15-minute inactivity timeout was detected.
Remediation options: 1. Configure a reverse proxy (nginx) in front of XO to enforce session idle timeouts using proxy_read_timeout and proxy_send_timeout directives set to 900 seconds (15 minutes). 2. Implement network-level session enforcement via firewall idle-connection timeout rules. 3. Contact Vates to request a configurable session idle timeout feature in a future XO release. 4. Document a compensating control accepted by the AO if a technical solution is not feasible.
Reference: The AO must accept this finding or document a compensating control in the SSP.

STIG Requirement: Administrator sessions must time out after 10 minutes of inactivity (APSC-DV-000080).
Xen Orchestra applies a single session expiration policy to all users and does not differentiate between administrator and non-privileged user sessions. The check found no per-role idle timeout configuration in config.toml, process environment, or source. The 10-minute administrator timeout requirement cannot be enforced through native XO configuration.
Remediation options: 1. Implement differentiated timeout enforcement via a reverse proxy (nginx) or load balancer that applies shorter session timeouts to administrative URL paths (e.g., /api/admin/*). 2. Configure administrative access through a privileged access workstation (PAW) or jump server that enforces 10-minute idle lockouts at the OS level. 3. Contact Vates to request role-based session timeout support in a future XO release. 4. Document this as an accepted risk with compensating controls in the SSP.
Reference: APSC-DV-000080. The AO must accept this finding or document a compensating control.

STIG Requirement: The application must provide a user-initiated logoff capability (APSC-DV-000090).
Xen Orchestra provides a built-in logoff capability through multiple mechanisms: - Web UI: Sign Out button accessible from the user menu in the top navigation bar terminates the session. - REST API: The /rest/v0/sessions/current endpoint accepts DELETE requests to invalidate the current session. - XO CLI: The xo-cli session.signOut command terminates the authenticated session programmatically.
Session termination is confirmed by verifying that authenticated API requests return HTTP 401 after logout. XO uses server-side session tokens stored in LevelDB; logout invalidates the token server-side, preventing reuse.
This finding is Not A Finding. Xen Orchestra fully satisfies the logoff capability requirement.

STIG Requirement: The application must provide a user-initiated logoff capability (APSC-DV-000090).
The automated check could not confirm XO's logout capability on this system. Possible causes: - XO process is not running or is not accessible on port 443. - The REST API endpoint /rest/v0/sessions/current is not responding. - XO is deployed behind a proxy that is filtering the check.
Manual verification steps: 1. Log in to the Xen Orchestra web interface. 2. Confirm a Sign Out or Logout option is present in the user menu. 3. Click Sign Out and verify you are redirected to the login page. 4. Attempt to access a protected resource after logout and confirm HTTP 401 is returned.
If manual verification confirms logout works, document the evidence and mark as NotAFinding in the CKL.

STIG Requirement: The application must display an explicit logoff message confirming session termination (APSC-DV-000100, CAT III).
The automated check searched the xo-web compiled JavaScript distribution for explicit session-terminated confirmation messages (e.g., "You have been logged out", "Session terminated"). While XO redirects users to the login page after logout, no explicit confirmation message text was detected in the source.
Manual verification steps: 1. Log in to the Xen Orchestra web interface. 2. Click Sign Out from the user menu. 3. Observe whether the application displays a message such as "You have been signed out" or "Session terminated successfully" before or after redirecting to the login page. 4. If such a message is displayed, document it with a screenshot and mark as NotAFinding. 5. If no message is displayed (only a redirect to login), this remains an Open finding.
Remediation: Request Vates add an explicit logout confirmation message to the XO web interface. This is a CAT III (low severity) finding. Document as accepted risk if remediation is not feasible.

Not Applicable: Xen Orchestra is a hypervisor management platform that manages VMs, hosts, and storage. It does not store or process classified, CUI, or user-defined data objects requiring security attribute labeling (e.g., classification markings). The STIG requires security attribute association only for applications that store data subject to mandatory access control (MAC) or sensitivity labeling policies. XO stores infrastructure configuration data (VM configs, user credentials, audit logs), not mission data. This requirement does not apply to infrastructure management software of this type.

Not Applicable: Xen Orchestra does not process classified, CUI, or sensitivity-labeled data objects requiring in-process security attribute association. XO processes infrastructure management data (API requests, VM operations, host metrics) that does not carry data classification markings. This STIG control applies to applications that process data subject to mandatory access control (MAC) policies where security attributes (classification, sensitivity labels) must be tracked through processing pipelines. XO is an infrastructure management tool, not a data processing application subject to data labeling requirements. This requirement does not apply.

Not Applicable: Xen Orchestra does not transmit classified, CUI, or sensitivity-labeled data objects requiring security attribute association during transmission. XO transmits infrastructure management data (API responses, VM state, metrics) over TLS-protected channels, but this data does not carry mandatory access control (MAC) classification labels that must travel with the data.
TLS confidentiality and integrity protection for XO API transmissions is covered separately by V-222396 (confidentiality) and V-222397 (integrity). This control specifically requires applications to embed and preserve data classification attributes (e.g., FOUO, SECRET) in transmitted messages. As an infrastructure management tool, XO does not handle data subject to this labeling requirement.

STIG Requirement: DoD-approved encryption (TLS 1.2 or higher) must protect all remote access sessions (APSC-DV-000160).
The automated check confirmed that Xen Orchestra accepts TLS 1.2 and/or TLS 1.3 connections on port 443, and TLS 1.0 (weak protocol) is disabled. This satisfies the DoD requirement for FIPS 140-2 approved encryption protecting session confidentiality.
TLS 1.2 and TLS 1.3 use AES-based cipher suites which are FIPS 140-2 approved. TLS 1.0 is disabled, eliminating known weaknesses (e.g., POODLE, BEAST). All XO API and web UI traffic is encrypted end-to-end.

STIG Requirement: DoD-approved encryption (TLS 1.2 or higher) must protect all remote access sessions (APSC-DV-000160).
The automated check detected one of the following conditions: - TLS 1.2 and TLS 1.3 are not active on port 443 (TLS not configured or not accessible). - TLS 1.0 is active alongside TLS 1.2/1.3 (weak protocol must be disabled).
Remediation steps: 1. Verify XO is listening on port 443: ss -tlnp | grep :443 2. Review config.toml for TLS certificate configuration (bindAddress, certificate, key fields). 3. Disable TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 in the Node.js TLS configuration using --tls-min-v1.2 flag or by setting minVersion: 'TLSv1.2' in the https.createServer options. 4. Restart the xo-server service: systemctl restart xo-server 5. Verify with: echo Q | openssl s_client -connect HOSTNAME:443 -tls1_2 2>&1 | grep "Cipher is"

STIG Requirement: Cryptographic mechanisms must protect the integrity of all remote access sessions (APSC-DV-000170).
The automated check confirmed that Xen Orchestra accepts TLS 1.2 and/or TLS 1.3 connections on port 443, and TLS 1.0 (which lacks adequate integrity protection) is disabled.
TLS 1.2 and TLS 1.3 use HMAC-based message authentication (e.g., HMAC-SHA256 in TLS 1.2, AEAD in TLS 1.3) to ensure integrity of all transmitted data. Any in-transit modification of encrypted TLS records is detected and the connection is terminated. This satisfies the DoD requirement for cryptographic integrity protection of remote access sessions.

STIG Requirement: Cryptographic mechanisms must protect the integrity of all remote access sessions (APSC-DV-000170).
The automated check detected one of the following conditions: - TLS 1.2 and TLS 1.3 are not active on port 443. - TLS 1.0 is active (does not provide adequate integrity protection and must be disabled).
Remediation steps: 1. Verify XO is listening on port 443: ss -tlnp | grep :443 2. Review config.toml for TLS certificate and key configuration. 3. Enforce minimum TLS 1.2 by adding --tls-min-v1.2 to xo-server startup parameters or setting minVersion: 'TLSv1.2' in Node.js https.createServer options. 4. Disable TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 explicitly. 5. Restart the xo-server service: systemctl restart xo-server 6. Re-test TLS configuration after restart.

Not Applicable: Xen Orchestra does not use SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol) for any of its interfaces.
XO exposes a REST/JSON API over HTTPS and a WebSocket JSON-RPC interface. Both are modern protocols that do not use XML-based SOAP messaging. Node.js/Express.js applications do not natively support SOAP. No SOAP, WSDL, or XML-RPC references were detected in the XO source code.
The STIG requirement applies only to applications that use SOAP messaging. Since XO does not use SOAP, this control does not apply. TLS-based integrity for XO's REST and WebSocket interfaces is covered by V-222397. This finding is Not Applicable.

The automated check detected potential SOAP, WSDL, or XML-RPC references in the Xen Orchestra source code.
Manual verification required: 1. Review the detected references to determine if they represent active SOAP endpoints or merely code comments, documentation, or library imports. 2. If active SOAP messaging is confirmed, verify that all SOAP messages include: - Message ID - Service Request element - Timestamp element - SAML Assertion (if applicable) - Digital signatures on all message elements 3. If no active SOAP endpoints are found, update the finding to Not_Applicable with supporting evidence.
If SOAP is confirmed but not properly secured, contact Vates to implement WS-Security digital signing.

Automated scan found no active SAML configuration in XO config files (/opt/xo/xo-server/config.toml or /etc/xo-server/config.toml). XO supports SAML via the @xen-orchestra/auth-saml plugin, but SAML is not enabled on this system. This control requires SAML authentication to be configured and active; since SAML is not in use, the control is Not Applicable.
If SAML is later enabled, this finding must be re-evaluated. The SAML IdP must generate a unique assertion ID (the saml:Assertion ID attribute) for every assertion it issues. Verify the IdP configuration enforces uniqueness â€” most modern IdPs (ADFS, Okta, Azure AD) do this by default.

Automated scan detected active SAML configuration in XO config.toml. XO delegates SAML assertion handling to the configured Identity Provider (IdP). This control requires the ISSO/ISSM to verify with the IdP administrator that:
1. The IdP generates a unique ID attribute for every SAML assertion issued to XO. 2. The XO SAML plugin does not accept assertions with duplicate or reused IDs. 3. The IdP enforces the uniqueness requirement per SAML 2.0 Core section 1.3.4.
Action required: Obtain documentation or configuration evidence from the IdP administrator confirming assertion ID uniqueness is enforced. Document the IdP product, version, and the uniqueness enforcement mechanism (e.g., ADFS enforces this by default via the AssertionID attribute generated as a GUID).

Automated scan confirmed XO (Xen Orchestra) uses a REST/JSON API architecture, not SOAP/WS-Security. WS-Security encrypted assertion tokens are a SOAP-specific mechanism (WS-Security standard, OASIS 2004). XO has no SOAP endpoint, no WS-Security middleware, and no assertion intermediary in the SOAP sense.
XO API communications occur over HTTPS (TLS), which provides equivalent confidentiality protection for all data in transit. Authentication uses JSON Web Token (JWT) session tokens issued over TLS, not SOAP assertion tokens passed through XML intermediaries. This control is Not Applicable because the technology (WS-Security/SOAP assertions) is not used by XO.
Note: If a future XO deployment introduces a SOAP-based integration gateway, this finding must be re-evaluated for that component.

Automated scan found no active SAML configuration on this system. The OneTimeUse element is a SAML 2.0 Conditions element restriction that prevents assertion replay. Since SAML is not configured, no SAML assertions are generated and this control does not apply.
If SAML is later enabled, verify: (1) the IdP only includes at most one OneTimeUse element per assertion Conditions block; (2) the XO SAML plugin enforces single-use assertion consumption and rejects replays. Most SAML 2.0-compliant IdPs enforce this automatically.

Automated scan detected active SAML configuration. SAML 2.0 Core (section 2.5.1.5) requires that the Conditions element contain at most one OneTimeUse element per assertion. XO delegates SAML assertion processing to the @xen-orchestra/auth-saml plugin and the upstream IdP.
Action required: The ISSO/ISSM must verify with the IdP administrator that: 1. The IdP never includes more than one OneTimeUse element in the Conditions block of any assertion sent to XO. 2. The XO SAML plugin enforces OneTimeUse semantics â€” each assertion is only accepted once (replay protection).
Document the IdP product, version, and the configuration or code reference confirming OneTimeUse enforcement. Common IdPs (ADFS, Okta, Azure AD) enforce this by default and may be documented by citing the product compliance statement.

Automated scan found no active SAML configuration on this system. The SessionIndex attribute is a SAML 2.0 element used in AuthnStatement to correlate the IdP session with the SP session. Since SAML is not configured, no SAML SessionIndex values are generated or transmitted, and this control does not apply.
If SAML is later enabled, verify: (1) all SAML messages containing a SessionIndex attribute are transmitted over encrypted channels (HTTPS/TLS); (2) the XO SAML plugin is configured to reject unencrypted SAML responses. XO's TLS-only API configuration provides this protection by default.

Automated scan detected active SAML configuration. SAML 2.0 SessionIndex values that are correlated with user privacy data must be transmitted only over encrypted channels.
Action required: The ISSO/ISSM must verify: 1. All SAML AuthnResponse and LogoutRequest messages containing SessionIndex are sent only over HTTPS (TLS 1.2 or higher). 2. The XO application does not accept SAML messages over plain HTTP. 3. The IdP is configured to only deliver assertions to the registered HTTPS Assertion Consumer Service (ACS) URL.
Verify the ACS URL registered in the IdP for XO uses https:// not http://. Document the IdP configuration and confirm TLS is enforced end-to-end between IdP and XO. XO's default TLS configuration (if properly configured) satisfies this requirement.

Automated scan detected LDAP or Active Directory integration configured in XO config.toml. LDAP/AD integration satisfies the requirement for automated account management mechanisms by delegating user provisioning, disabling, and removal to the enterprise directory service.
This means: (1) when a user account is disabled or deleted in Active Directory, XO authentication fails automatically at the next login attempt; (2) account creation, modification, and termination workflows are handled by the enterprise IdM/IdP system (e.g., AD, LDAP); (3) XO local account management is supplemented by the directory service's automated account lifecycle controls.
The ISSO/ISSM should document the LDAP/AD integration as the automated account management mechanism in the system's authorization artifacts.

Automated scan found no LDAP or Active Directory integration in XO config files. XO is operating with local account management only, which requires manual administrative action for each account lifecycle event.
Action required to achieve compliance: 1. Configure LDAP/AD integration in XO config.toml under the [ldap] section (or equivalent SAML/OIDC integration). 2. Alternatively, integrate XO with an enterprise Identity Management (IdM) system that provides automated provisioning/deprovisioning via SCIM or LDAP.
Without automated account management, the ISSO/ISSM must document a compensating control: a manual account review process with a defined schedule (recommend monthly) and documented evidence of reviews. This compensating control must be approved in the ATO package.
Reference: config.toml LDAP configuration requires: ldap.url, ldap.bindDn, ldap.bindPassword, ldap.filter, and ldap.base entries.

Automated scan confirmed XO does not have a native mechanism to automatically expire or disable temporary accounts after 72 hours. XO account management is primarily through the web UI or xo-cli; there is no built-in account expiry field or scheduled deprovisioning job.
Action required (choose one): 1. LDAP/AD integration: Configure temporary accounts in Active Directory with an account expiration set to 72 hours from creation. XO will inherit the AD account expiry automatically. 2. Administrative procedure: Implement a documented manual process where administrators create temporary accounts and schedule removal within 72 hours. The process must include: (a) a creation log with timestamp, (b) a scheduled reminder or ticket, (c) evidence of removal/disabling within 72 hours. 3. External automation: Use the XO REST API (/rest/v0/users) with a scheduled job (cron/systemd timer) to disable or remove accounts created more than 72 hours ago.
Document the chosen approach in the ISSO/ISSM authorization artifacts. If no temporary accounts are ever provisioned on this system, document that policy as a compensating control.

Automated scan found no emergency account designation or protection mechanism in XO. XO does not implement a concept of "emergency accounts" (also called break-glass or PACE accounts) as a distinct account type with protected status. All XO administrator accounts have equal administrative rights and can be enabled or disabled by any other administrator.
Emergency access to the underlying XO infrastructure is handled at the operating system level (Debian 12 root account, SSH key-based access) rather than within the XO application itself. The operating system emergency access controls are assessed separately under the GPOS SRG for Debian 12.
Since XO has no application-level emergency account feature or account type distinction, this control is Not Applicable. Document this assessment in the authorization artifacts noting that emergency system access relies on OS-level administrative mechanisms.

Automated scan found no native inactivity-based account disable mechanism in XO. XO does not track last-login timestamps for accounts or automatically disable accounts after a period of inactivity. The XO LevelDB database stores user credentials but does not implement inactivity enforcement.
Action required (choose one): 1. LDAP/AD integration: Configure Active Directory with the "Account is disabled after N days of inactivity" Group Policy Object (GPO). Set the threshold to 35 days. AD will disable accounts automatically; XO inherits this via LDAP authentication failure. 2. Administrative procedure: Implement a documented manual process where administrators review XO audit logs (or the XO user list via xo-cli) monthly and disable accounts with no login activity in the past 35 days. Document evidence of reviews. 3. External automation: Use the XO REST API (/rest/v0/users) with a scheduled job that compares user last-activity timestamps from audit logs against the 35-day threshold.
Document the chosen approach in the ISSO/ISSM authorization artifacts with evidence that inactivity monitoring is active and enforced.

Automated scan enumerated XO user accounts from the LevelDB database or XO REST API. The scan cannot automatically determine which accounts are "unnecessary" â€” this requires human judgment based on current organizational roles and responsibilities.
Action required: 1. Review the list of XO user accounts displayed in the Finding Details section. 2. For each account, verify that the account holder: (a) is a current employee or contractor, (b) still requires access to XO for their job function, (c) has the minimum required role (no excessive permissions). 3. Disable or delete any accounts for: former employees, transferred personnel no longer needing access, test/demo accounts, shared accounts with no current business justification, or service accounts for decommissioned integrations. 4. Document the account review with: reviewer name, date, accounts reviewed, actions taken, and justification for retained accounts.
Schedule periodic account reviews (recommend every 30 days) and maintain documentation as evidence for ATO compliance. Use "xo-cli --list-users" or the XO web UI (Settings > Users) to perform the review.

Automated scan found no auth-ldap plugin configured and no account creation events in the systemd journal for the last 7 days. This is expected on systems where no account changes have been made recently.
ACTION REQUIRED - ISSO/ISSM must verify one of the following: 1. Enable the XO audit plugin (xo-server-audit) which records all API operations including user.create events 2. Confirm XO audit logs are being forwarded to a SIEM that captures account creation events 3. Manually create a test account and verify the event is logged in the system journal or audit log
To enable the XO audit plugin: navigate to Settings > Plugins in the XO web interface and enable xo-server-audit. Once enabled, all user management actions are logged to the XO audit log and accessible via the REST API at /rest/v0/plugins/audit/records.
If using LDAP/AD for account management, configure the auth-ldap plugin to satisfy this as Not Applicable.

Automated scan detected the auth-ldap plugin is installed and configured. Account management is delegated to the enterprise LDAP/AD directory service, which maintains its own comprehensive audit trail of all account lifecycle events including creation.
ISSO must verify: Active Directory audit policy (Account Management category) is enabled and logs are retained per DoD policy (minimum 1 year online, 3 years archived). AD account creation events appear as Event ID 4720 in the Windows Security Event Log.

Automated scan found account creation events in the systemd journal. XO is logging account creation activity as required by this control.
ISSO should verify: The XO audit plugin (xo-server-audit) is enabled and logs include account name and timestamp at minimum. Audit logs should be retained per DoD requirements and forwarded to a centralized audit server.

Automated scan found no auth-ldap plugin configured and no account modification events in the systemd journal for the last 7 days.
ACTION REQUIRED - ISSO/ISSM must verify one of the following: 1. Enable the XO audit plugin (xo-server-audit) to capture user.set events (account modifications) 2. Confirm XO audit logs are forwarded to a SIEM that captures account modification events 3. Manually modify a test account and verify the event appears in the audit log
XO account modification events via the audit plugin include role changes, password changes, and permission updates.

Automated scan detected the auth-ldap plugin is configured. Account management is delegated to enterprise LDAP/AD, which maintains its own audit trail. Account modification events in AD appear as Event ID 4738 (user account changed) in the Windows Security Event Log.
ISSO must verify AD audit policy covers account management changes and logs are retained per DoD policy.
Automated scan found account modification events in the systemd journal. XO is logging account modification activity as required. ISSO should verify audit log retention and centralized forwarding.

Automated scan found no auth-ldap plugin configured and no account disabling events in the systemd journal for the last 7 days.
ACTION REQUIRED - ISSO/ISSM must verify: 1. Enable the XO audit plugin (xo-server-audit) to capture account disable events 2. Confirm audit logs are forwarded to a centralized SIEM 3. Test by disabling a non-production account and verifying the event is logged
Note: XO does not have a native "disable account" feature separate from deletion. Accounts may be disabled by removing permissions or by the LDAP/AD directory if configured.

Automated scan detected the auth-ldap plugin is configured. Account disabling is managed by enterprise LDAP/AD. Account disable events in AD appear as Event ID 4725 (user account disabled).
ISSO must verify AD audit policy is enabled and logs retained per DoD policy.
Automated scan found account disabling events in the systemd journal. XO is logging account disabling activity as required. ISSO should verify audit log retention and centralized forwarding.

Automated scan found no auth-ldap plugin configured and no account removal events in the systemd journal for the last 7 days.
ACTION REQUIRED - ISSO/ISSM must verify: 1. Enable the XO audit plugin (xo-server-audit) to capture user deletion events 2. Confirm audit logs are forwarded to a centralized SIEM 3. Test by deleting a non-production account and verifying the event is logged
Account deletion in XO is logged as a user.delete action in the audit log when the audit plugin is enabled.

Automated scan detected the auth-ldap plugin is configured. Account removal is managed by enterprise LDAP/AD. Account deletion events in AD appear as Event ID 4726 (user account deleted).
ISSO must verify AD audit policy is enabled and logs retained per DoD policy.
Automated scan found account removal events in the systemd journal. XO is logging account removal activity as required. ISSO should verify audit log retention and centralized forwarding.

Automated scan found no auth-ldap plugin configured. XO does not natively send notifications to SAs/ISSOs when accounts are created.
ACTION REQUIRED - ISSO/ISSM must implement a compensating control: Option 1 (SIEM): Configure SIEM to alert SA/ISSO when XO audit log records a user.create event Option 2 (ITSM): Require all account creation requests to go through a ticketing system (ServiceNow, Jira) that automatically notifies SA/ISSO via email/ticket assignment Option 3 (Script): Deploy a monitoring script that polls the XO API /rest/v0/plugins/audit/records and sends email alerts when new user.create events are detected
Document the implemented compensating control in the System Security Plan.

Automated scan detected the auth-ldap plugin is configured. Account creation notifications to SA/ISSO are handled by the enterprise LDAP/AD directory service processes and procedures.
ISSO must verify the enterprise AD account management process includes SA/ISSO notification on account creation per DoD account management procedures.

Automated scan found no auth-ldap plugin configured. XO does not natively notify SA/ISSO when accounts are modified.
ACTION REQUIRED - Implement a compensating control: Option 1: Configure SIEM to alert on user.set events from XO audit log Option 2: Require account modification requests through an ITSM system with automatic SA/ISSO notification Option 3: Deploy monitoring script polling XO API for account modification events
Significant account modifications include: role changes, permission updates, password resets, and group membership changes. All of these are captured by the XO audit plugin when enabled.

Automated scan detected the auth-ldap plugin is configured. Account modification notifications are handled by enterprise LDAP/AD directory service procedures. ISSO must verify the AD account management process includes SA/ISSO notification on account changes.

Automated scan found no auth-ldap plugin configured. XO does not natively notify SA/ISSO when accounts are disabled.
ACTION REQUIRED - Implement a compensating control for account disable notifications: Option 1: Configure SIEM to alert SA/ISSO when XO audit log records an account disable event Option 2: Require account disable requests through ITSM with automatic SA/ISSO notification workflow Option 3: Establish manual procedure where any XO account disablement triggers immediate SA/ISSO email notification
Document the implemented procedure in the System Security Plan and ensure it is tested annually.

Automated scan detected the auth-ldap plugin is configured. Account disabling notifications are handled by enterprise LDAP/AD procedures. ISSO must verify AD procedures include SA/ISSO notification on account disabling per DoD account management policy.

Automated scan found no auth-ldap plugin configured. XO does not natively notify SA/ISSO when accounts are removed.
ACTION REQUIRED - Implement a compensating control for account removal notifications: Option 1: Configure SIEM to alert SA/ISSO when XO audit log records a user.delete event Option 2: Require account removal requests through ITSM with automatic SA/ISSO notification Option 3: Establish manual procedure requiring SA/ISSO acknowledgment before any XO account deletion
Account removal is a high-risk event. SA/ISSO notification allows verification that removal was authorized and prevents unauthorized account deletion from going undetected.

Automated scan detected the auth-ldap plugin is configured. Account removal notifications are handled by enterprise LDAP/AD procedures. ISSO must verify AD procedures include SA/ISSO notification on account removal per DoD account management policy.

Automated scan found no auth-ldap plugin configured and no account enabling events in the systemd journal for the last 7 days.
ACTION REQUIRED - ISSO/ISSM must verify: 1. Enable the XO audit plugin (xo-server-audit) to capture account enable/unlock events 2. Confirm audit logs are forwarded to a centralized SIEM 3. Test by unlocking/re-enabling an account and verifying the event is logged
When an account is re-enabled in XO (e.g., after lockout), the event should be captured by the audit plugin and logged with the account name, timestamp, and the admin who performed the action.

Automated scan detected the auth-ldap plugin is configured. Account enabling events are managed by enterprise LDAP/AD. Account unlock events in AD appear as Event ID 4767 (user account unlocked).
ISSO must verify AD audit policy covers account management and logs are retained per DoD policy.
Automated scan found account enabling events in the systemd journal. XO is logging account enabling activity as required. ISSO should verify audit log retention and centralized forwarding.

Automated scan found no auth-ldap plugin configured. XO does not natively notify SA/ISSO when accounts are enabled/unlocked.
ACTION REQUIRED - Implement a compensating control for account enabling notifications: Option 1: Configure SIEM to alert SA/ISSO when XO audit log records an account enable/unlock event Option 2: Require account enable requests through ITSM with automatic SA/ISSO notification Option 3: Establish manual procedure requiring SA/ISSO acknowledgment for any account re-enablement
Account re-enablement after lockout should be tracked to detect potential brute-force unlock attempts.

Automated scan detected the auth-ldap plugin is configured. Account enabling notifications are handled by enterprise LDAP/AD procedures. ISSO must verify AD procedures include SA/ISSO notification on account enabling actions per DoD account management policy.

Automated scan identified the following data elements managed by Xen Orchestra that require data protection classification and documentation:
- User credentials (bcrypt-hashed passwords stored in LevelDB at /var/lib/xo-server) - Authentication tokens (stored in memory/Redis, scoped to session) - VM configuration data (stored in LevelDB, includes network configs, storage paths) - XCP-ng host connection credentials (stored in LevelDB, may include passwords) - SSL/TLS private keys (stored at /etc/ssl or /opt/xo) - Audit log records (stored via xo-server-audit plugin)
ACTION REQUIRED - ISSO must produce documentation that: 1. Identifies each data element and its sensitivity/classification level 2. Documents the protection requirements for each element (encryption, access control, retention) 3. Describes implemented protections (TLS in transit, file permissions, key management) 4. Is reviewed annually and updated when the application changes
This documentation is required by APSC-DV-000440 and must be available for auditor review.

Automated scan found no explicit data mining detection controls configured in Xen Orchestra.
ACTION REQUIRED - ISSO must provide one of the following: Option A (Not Applicable determination): If the organization has determined that data mining protections are not required for the XO management plane (e.g., because it only stores hypervisor management metadata, not sensitive user data), document this determination with ISSO/ISSM signature and reference in the System Security Plan.
Option B (Detection controls): If data mining protections are required, implement: 1. Rate limiting: Configure XO API rate limits to detect/prevent bulk data extraction 2. SIEM monitoring: Alert on unusually high API call volumes from a single user/IP 3. Session monitoring: Track and alert on bulk VM/storage enumeration operations 4. Access logging: Ensure all API access is logged with user identity for forensic analysis
XO REST API calls are logged when the audit plugin is enabled, providing a baseline for anomaly detection.

Xen Orchestra implements Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) with Admin, Operator, Viewer, and No Access roles per resource pool. It does not implement Discretionary Access Control (DAC), which requires subjects (users) to set permissions on objects they own (e.g., Unix file ACLs, Windows DACLs). In XO, all access control is centrally administered by administrators, not by object owners. The STIG check states: "If the application does not implement DAC, this requirement is N/A." This requirement is Not Applicable to Xen Orchestra.

Xen Orchestra is a virtualization management platform and does not implement information flow control policies within the system. It does not enforce data classification labels, security levels (e.g., Unclassified/Secret/Top Secret), or mandatory access control (MAC/MLS) for data flowing between application components. XO's API enforces RBAC for access control but does not enforce information flow based on sensitivity labels. The STIG check states: "If the application does not provide data flow control capabilities, this requirement is N/A." This requirement is Not Applicable to Xen Orchestra.

Xen Orchestra communicates with XCP-ng hosts via XAPI (XML-RPC over TLS) but does not implement information flow control policies between interconnected systems. It does not enforce data classification-based flow control, cross-domain transfer guards, or security label enforcement on data crossing system boundaries. XO enforces TLS encryption and RBAC for inter-system API calls but not classification-based flow control. The STIG check states: "If the application does not provide data flow control capabilities, this requirement is N/A." This requirement is Not Applicable to Xen Orchestra.

The xo-server process runs as a dedicated non-root service account (not UID 0). XO also enforces RBAC at the application layer: non-privileged users (Operator, Viewer roles) cannot disable security safeguards, modify system configuration, manage encryption keys, or perform administrative functions. The application-level privilege separation is enforced by the XO API regardless of the OS user account used to start the service. Automated check confirmed process owner is non-root with no membership in privileged OS groups (sudo/wheel/adm).

The xo-server process is running as root (UID 0) or a privileged OS account. This means all XO users inherit elevated OS privileges, violating the principle of least privilege.
Remediation steps: 1. Create a dedicated service account: useradd -r -s /bin/false xo-server 2. Set ownership: chown -R xo-server:xo-server /opt/xo /var/lib/xo-server 3. Update systemd unit file to run as the service account: [Service] User=xo-server Group=xo-server 4. Reload and restart: systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl restart xo-server 5. Verify process owner: ps -eo user,comm | grep node
Note: XO application-level RBAC (Admin/Operator/Viewer roles) is independent of the OS process user and should remain functional after this change.

The XO audit plugin is installed and loaded. Privileged function executions are recorded in audit logs including: user account creation/modification/deletion, ACL assignments, server additions/removals, plugin configuration changes, and user sign-in/sign-out events. Each audit record includes the action type, timestamp, and the user who performed it. Audit records are accessible via the REST API at /rest/v0/plugins/audit/records and are also written to the systemd journal under the xo-server unit.

The XO audit plugin was not detected as loaded, or audit records of privileged function executions could not be confirmed. Privileged function executions (user management, config changes, key management) must be recorded with the action, date, and time.
Remediation steps: 1. Install the XO audit plugin if not present: cd /opt/xo && yarn add @xen-orchestra/audit-core 2. Enable the audit plugin in XO web UI: Settings > Plugins > audit > Enable 3. Configure audit log retention in the plugin settings 4. Verify by performing a privileged action (e.g., create a test user) and checking: GET /rest/v0/plugins/audit/records?limit=10 5. Confirm the action, date/time, and user are recorded in the response
Note: If LDAP/AD authentication is used, ensure authentication events are also captured in the centralized audit server per V-222422 requirements.

Account unlock process requires ISSO/ISSM interview verification. The process cannot be fully automated. The approved account unlock procedure must meet all of the following criteria:
Required procedure elements (STIG requirement): 1. Written procedure document with ISSO and ISSM approval signatures 2. Identity verification step â€” administrator must confirm user identity before unlocking 3. Ticket/request workflow creating an auditable trail for each unlock event 4. Documentation of the business justification for the unlock
XO Account Unlock Methods available to the administrator: - Web UI: Admin > Users > select user > toggle "Enabled" state - CLI: xo-cli user.set id=<user-uuid> enabled=true - API: PATCH /rest/v0/users/<uuid> {"enabled": true}
To satisfy this requirement: 1. Create a Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) document for account unlocks 2. Obtain ISSO and ISSM approval and signatures on the SOP 3. Implement a ticketing workflow (e.g., ServiceNow, JIRA) for unlock requests 4. Train administrators on the identity verification step 5. Retain records of all unlock events for audit purposes

The Standard Mandatory DoD Notice and Consent Banner is displayed on the XO login page before granting access. Automated check confirmed banner keywords are present in the login page HTML. The approved DoD banner text includes the required elements: notification of monitoring, prohibition of unauthorized use, and user consent to monitoring conditions.

The DoD Notice and Consent Banner was not detected on the XO login page. XO Community Edition does not include a built-in banner feature. The banner must be implemented via one of the following methods:
Option 1 â€” Nginx reverse proxy pre-authentication page (recommended): 1. Install nginx: apt-get install -y nginx 2. Create a consent page that displays the DoD banner with an Accept button 3. Configure nginx to require banner acknowledgment before proxying to XO: - Serve consent.html at / - Redirect to /xo/ after acceptance (using a session cookie) 4. Configure XO to listen only on localhost (127.0.0.1) 5. Test: browse to XO URL and verify banner appears before login page
Option 2 â€” Network-level pre-authentication page: Configure a captive portal or network access control system to present the banner before granting network access to the XO server.
Required DoD banner text (abbreviated â€” use full approved text): "You are accessing a U.S. Government (USG) Information System (IS) that is provided for USG-authorized use only. By using this IS, you consent to monitoring of your use..."
Reference: DoD CIO memorandum on Standard Mandatory DoD Notice and Consent Banner.

The DoD Notice and Consent Banner is retained on screen until the user explicitly acknowledges it. An acknowledgment mechanism (Accept button, checkbox, or equivalent) is present on the banner page. Users cannot proceed to the XO login page until they take an explicit action to accept the banner. Automated check confirmed both banner text and acknowledgment keywords are present in the login page or pre-authentication page.

The DoD banner acknowledgment mechanism was not detected. The banner must be retained until the user takes an explicit action to accept it â€” simply displaying it without requiring acknowledgment does not satisfy this requirement.
Implementation requirements: 1. The banner page must include an explicit acceptance mechanism (one of): - A checkbox: "I acknowledge and accept the above terms" + Submit button - An "I Accept" button that the user must click to proceed - A typed-acknowledgment field requiring the user to type "I AGREE" 2. The banner must block access to the XO login page until accepted 3. A session cookie should be set after acknowledgment to avoid repeated banners per session
Sample nginx consent page implementation: - Serve a consent.html with the full DoD banner text - Include: <input type="checkbox" id="accept"> I acknowledge these terms <button onclick="if(document.getElementById('accept').checked){window.location='/xo/'}">Continue</button> - Block direct access to /xo/ without the consent cookie set
Note: Both V-222434 (display banner) and V-222435 (require acknowledgment) must be satisfied simultaneously. Implementing both with a single nginx pre-auth page is the recommended approach.

Automated check detected DoD mandatory notice and consent banner content on the XO login page. The banner includes required DoD keywords. ISSO action: Verify the full banner text matches the DoD Standard Mandatory Notice and Consent Banner exactly. Document the banner source (nginx consent page, reverse proxy redirect, or application-level splash page).

No DoD mandatory notice and consent banner was detected on the XO login page. Xen Orchestra does not include a native pre-login banner mechanism. ISSO action: Implement a DoD consent banner via one of the following methods: (1) Nginx reverse proxy consent page before forwarding to XO; (2) XO customization via GUI/branding plugin; (3) Network access point banner (router/firewall warning). The banner must include: unauthorized use is prohibited, activities are monitored, evidence of unauthorized use may result in criminal prosecution. Reference VATES_COMPLIANCE_BLOCKERS.md BANNER-001 for implementation guidance.

Automated check detected last successful logon display on the XO application. The application presents the time/date of the user's last successful logon after authentication. ISSO action: Verify the last logon display is visible to users immediately after login and includes at minimum the date and time of the previous successful authentication.

Xen Orchestra does not display the time and date of the user's last successful logon. ISSO action: Implement last logon display via one of the following: (1) XO custom plugin that queries audit records for last login event; (2) Nginx/reverse proxy post-login redirect with last logon information; (3) LDAP/AD integration that surfaces last logon from directory services. Document this as an accepted risk or submit a waiver if implementation is not feasible. Reference VATES_COMPLIANCE_BLOCKERS.md BANNER-001 for related guidance.

Automated check confirmed XO provides non-repudiation through user-attributed audit records. The XO audit plugin captures each action with userId, action type, and timestamp. ISSO action: Verify audit records cannot be modified or deleted by users whose actions are recorded. Document the audit record retention policy and integrity protection mechanisms.

Non-repudiation for XO user actions requires manual verification. XO audit plugin records user actions with userId attribution but does not cryptographically sign individual records. ISSO action: (1) Verify XO audit plugin is active and recording all user actions; (2) Verify audit records are protected from modification (immutable storage or SIEM forwarding); (3) Verify records contain sufficient attribution (userId, timestamp, action, target); (4) Consider forwarding audit records to a SIEM for integrity protection. Document the non-repudiation controls as compensating measures in the ATO package.

System clock is synchronized via NTP/Chrony. XO audit records use the synchronized system clock for timestamping, enabling time-correlated aggregation with audit records from other systems. ISSO action: Verify NTP is synchronized to an authoritative government time source. Document the NTP server configuration and synchronization frequency.

NTP time synchronization not confirmed for this system. Without synchronized clocks, audit records from multiple systems cannot be reliably correlated. ISSO action: (1) Configure chronyd or systemd-timesyncd to use DoD-approved NTP servers; (2) Verify synchronization: timedatectl show | grep NTPSynchronized; (3) Set polling interval appropriate for the organization tolerance level; (4) Document the authoritative time source in the system security plan.

XO generates audit records when session IDs are created (user login). The XO audit plugin records authentication events including user login, which creates a new session. Journal logs confirm session creation events are captured with user identity and timestamp. ISSO action: Verify audit records for session creation include: user ID, source IP, timestamp, and outcome.

Session ID creation audit record generation requires manual verification. ISSO action: (1) Verify XO audit plugin is installed and active; (2) Perform a test login and verify an audit record was created; (3) Confirm the audit record includes: userId, action=session.signIn, timestamp, IP address; (4) Verify audit records are retained per the organization retention policy.

XO generates audit records when session IDs are destroyed (user logout). The XO audit plugin records logout events (session.signOut) with user identity and timestamp. Session destruction events are captured when users explicitly log out or tokens expire. ISSO action: Verify audit records for session destruction include: user ID, timestamp, and session identifier.

Session ID destruction audit record generation requires manual verification. ISSO action: (1) Verify XO audit plugin is installed and active; (2) Perform a test logout and verify an audit record was created; (3) Confirm the audit record includes: userId, action=session.signOut, timestamp; (4) Verify session expiration (timeout) also generates an audit record.

XO generates audit records when session IDs are renewed. Session renewal or token refresh events are captured in the audit trail. ISSO action: Verify the audit plugin captures token renewal events and confirm the records include userId, session identifier, and timestamp.

Session ID renewal audit record generation requires manual verification. XO may use rolling session tokens without explicit renewal audit records. ISSO action: (1) Review XO session management configuration (config.toml session settings); (2) Verify whether token renewal generates an audit event; (3) If no renewal audit exists, document as accepted risk or implement via custom logging middleware; (4) Consider enabling rolling session logging in the XO configuration.

No sensitive data (passwords, credentials, tokens) detected in XO application logs. XO Winston logger does not record authentication credentials or session tokens in log output. ISSO action: Periodically review logs to confirm no sensitive data is written. Verify the Winston log level is set to exclude debug-level password data in production.

Possible sensitive data detected in XO application logs. ISSO action: (1) Review the flagged log files for actual sensitive data exposure; (2) Verify NODE_ENV=production is set (suppresses verbose debug logging); (3) Review Winston logger configuration for log level and format settings; (4) Ensure authentication middleware does not log passwords or tokens; (5) Implement log scrubbing if sensitive data is confirmed in logs.

XO generates audit records when sessions time out. Session timeout events are captured in the audit trail with user identity and timestamp. ISSO action: Verify audit records for session timeouts include: userId, session identifier, and the reason for termination (timeout vs explicit logout).

Session timeout audit record generation requires manual verification. Session timeout events may not generate distinct audit records in XO. ISSO action: (1) Configure session timeout in XO (config.toml or environment variables); (2) Test session timeout and verify an audit/log event is generated; (3) If no timeout audit exists, implement via session expiration middleware; (4) Document as compensating control if session timeout logging is not natively supported.

XO audit records include timestamps for all events. systemd journal entries have system timestamps; XO audit plugin uses Unix millisecond timestamps. Winston logger produces ISO 8601 formatted timestamps. ISSO action: Verify all audit record sources (journal, XO audit, nginx access log) include timestamps with sufficient granularity (seconds or better).

Timestamp recording in XO audit records requires manual verification. ISSO action: (1) Retrieve a sample audit record: GET /rest/v0/plugins/audit/records?limit=5; (2) Verify each record has a time field in Unix milliseconds; (3) Verify systemd journal entries include system timestamps; (4) Verify Winston log format includes timestamp configuration.

XO generates audit records that include HTTP headers (User-Agent, method, path). Nginx access logs are configured to capture User-Agent, Referer, and HTTP method. ISSO action: Verify the nginx combined log format is active and access logs are retained per the organization audit log retention policy.

HTTP header audit record generation requires manual verification. ISSO action: (1) Verify nginx access_log is enabled with combined format (includes User-Agent, Referer); (2) Verify the log_format includes: $remote_addr, $request, $status, $http_user_agent, $http_referer; (3) If XO is accessed directly (no nginx), verify XO/Express.js logs HTTP headers via morgan middleware; (4) Retain nginx access logs per organizational policy (minimum 1 year for DoD systems).

XO generates audit records that include connecting system IP addresses. Nginx access logs capture client IP ($remote_addr) and X-Forwarded-For headers. ISSO action: Verify client IP addresses are accurately recorded even when behind a load balancer or reverse proxy (trust proxy setting may be required in Express.js).

Connecting system IP address audit record generation requires manual verification. ISSO action: (1) Verify nginx access_log captures $remote_addr for each request; (2) If behind a load balancer, configure nginx real_ip_header to capture original client IP; (3) Verify XO audit plugin records the requesting IP address in each audit record; (4) Test with a known client IP and confirm it appears in access logs.

XO audit records include the username/user ID for each event. The XO audit plugin records the userId for every action in the audit trail. ISSO action: Verify each audit record includes a non-null userId field. Confirm that unauthenticated actions (failed logins) record the attempted username.

Username/user ID in audit records requires manual verification. ISSO action: (1) Retrieve a sample audit record: GET /rest/v0/plugins/audit/records?limit=5; (2) Verify each record has a userId or subject field identifying the user; (3) Perform a test action and verify the audit record contains your user ID; (4) Verify failed authentication attempts also record the attempted username.

XO generates audit records for privilege grant attempts. The XO audit plugin logs ACL changes, role assignments, and permission modifications. Both successful and unsuccessful privilege grant attempts are captured with userId and timestamp. ISSO action: Verify audit records for privilege changes include: granting user ID, target user ID, privilege granted, and outcome.

Privilege grant attempt audit record generation requires manual verification. ISSO action: (1) Verify XO audit plugin is active and logging ACL/permission changes; (2) Test: assign a role to a user and verify an audit record is created; (3) Confirm the audit record includes: userId (granter), targetUserId, action, privilege level; (4) Verify failed privilege escalation attempts also generate audit records.

XO generates audit records for security object access attempts. The XO audit plugin logs all user interactions with security objects (VMs, hosts, storage, networks). Both successful and unsuccessful access attempts are recorded with userId and timestamp. ISSO action: Verify audit records for security object access include: userId, object type/ID, action performed, and outcome (success/failure).

Security object access audit record generation requires manual verification. ISSO action: (1) Verify XO audit plugin is active and logging resource access events; (2) Test: access a VM and verify an audit record is created; (3) Test: attempt access to a resource without permission and verify audit record is created; (4) Confirm audit records include: userId, objectType, objectId, action, outcome.

XO generates audit records for security level access attempts. XO uses RBAC (Admin, Operator, Viewer roles) rather than MAC security levels. The XO audit plugin logs all actions with role context, capturing access attempts at different privilege levels. ISSO action: Verify audit records reflect the user role level and capture both authorized and unauthorized access attempts across privilege boundaries.

Security level access audit record generation requires manual verification. ISSO action: (1) Verify XO audit plugin is active and logging RBAC role-based access events; (2) Test: attempt an admin-only action with a viewer account and verify audit record is created; (3) Confirm audit records capture cross-role access attempts; (4) Document XO RBAC model as the mechanism satisfying security level access control audit requirement.

Xen Orchestra does not implement data classification categories, MAC security labels, or compartmentalized data protection. XO is a virtualization management platform that uses RBAC (Admin/Operator/Viewer roles) â€” not data classification levels. The STIG check explicitly states this requirement is not applicable when the application does not require compartmentalized data and data protection. This condition applies to XO deployments.

Automated check detected the XO audit plugin is active. The XO audit plugin records all ACL and role modification events (addAcl, removeAcl, setAcl) which constitute privilege modification attempts in XO's RBAC model. Both successful and unsuccessful privilege modification attempts are captured with userId, action type, timestamp, and target object. ISSO action: Verify audit records include the granting user ID, target user/object, privilege modified, and outcome. Confirm audit records are retained per the organization retention policy.

Automated check could not confirm the XO audit plugin is active. Privilege modification audit records may not be generated. ISSO action: (1) Install and activate the @xen-orchestra/audit plugin; (2) Test: assign and revoke a role for a test user; (3) Verify audit records capture: userId (admin performing change), targetUserId, action (addAcl/removeAcl), privilege level, and outcome; (4) Verify failed privilege modification attempts also generate audit records.

Xen Orchestra does not implement classified security objects or data elements with privilege/classification designations. XO manages virtual infrastructure resources (VMs, hosts, storage, networks) using RBAC access controls, not object-level security classification labels. This requirement for security object modification auditing does not apply to XO deployments.

Xen Orchestra uses RBAC (Admin/Operator/Viewer) and does not implement MAC security levels, security domains, or multilevel security (MLS) classifications. RBAC role changes (privilege modifications) are audited under V-222454. This MAC-specific security level modification requirement does not apply to XO deployments.

Xen Orchestra does not store or process classified information and does not implement data classification categories or compartmentalized data protection. The STIG check explicitly states this requirement is not applicable when the application does not require compartmentalized data protection. This condition applies to XO deployments.

Automated check detected the XO audit plugin is active. The XO audit plugin records all ACL and role deletion events (removeAcl, deleteAcl operations) which constitute privilege deletion attempts in XO's RBAC model. Both successful and unsuccessful privilege deletion attempts are captured with userId, action type, timestamp, and target. ISSO action: Verify audit records include the user performing the deletion, the target user/object, the privilege deleted, and the outcome. Confirm audit records are retained per the organization retention policy.

Automated check could not confirm the XO audit plugin is active. Privilege deletion audit records may not be generated. ISSO action: (1) Install and activate the @xen-orchestra/audit plugin; (2) Test: remove a role from a test user; (3) Verify audit records capture: userId (admin), targetUserId, action (removeAcl), privilege level, and outcome; (4) Verify failed deletion attempts also generate audit records.

Xen Orchestra uses RBAC (Admin/Operator/Viewer) and does not implement MAC security levels or multilevel security domains. The deletion of security level permissions is not a supported operation in XO. RBAC role removals (privilege deletions) are audited under V-222458. This MAC-specific requirement does not apply to XO deployments.

Xen Orchestra stores its state in LevelDB (a key-value store) and does not implement a relational database with security-labeled objects or data elements. XO does not support compartmentalized data classification for database records. This database security object deletion requirement does not apply to XO deployments.

Xen Orchestra does not store classified or categorized information and does not implement data classification categories. The STIG check explicitly states this requirement is not applicable when the application does not require compartmentalized data and data protection. This condition applies to XO deployments.

Automated check detected the XO audit plugin is active. XO records session.signIn events for all authentication attempts. The audit plugin captures: userId, action (session.signIn), timestamp, source IP address, and outcome. Failed authentication attempts are also recorded. systemd journal provides additional authentication event logging. ISSO action: Verify audit records include successful logins (userId + timestamp) and failed login attempts (attempted username + reason). Confirm records are retained per the organization retention policy.

Automated check could not confirm the XO audit plugin is active. Logon attempt audit records may not be generated. ISSO action: (1) Install and activate the @xen-orchestra/audit plugin; (2) Perform a successful login and verify session.signIn audit record was created; (3) Perform a failed login and verify it is recorded; (4) Confirm records include: userId, action=session.signIn, timestamp, source IP, outcome.

Automated check detected the XO audit plugin is active. XO audit plugin captures all privileged activities including: VM lifecycle operations (start/stop/snapshot/migrate), host management (patch/reboot/maintenance), user management, ACL changes, server configuration, and pool operations. All records include userId, action, target object ID, and timestamp. ISSO action: Verify audit records capture the full range of admin operations. Test by performing a VM snapshot as admin and confirm the audit record shows your userId, the action, and the VM ID.

Automated check could not confirm the XO audit plugin is active. Privileged activity audit records may not be generated. ISSO action: (1) Install and activate the @xen-orchestra/audit plugin; (2) Perform a privileged action (start a VM, add a user, change an ACL); (3) Verify audit record includes: userId, action type, target object, timestamp; (4) Verify system-level access events (host management, pool operations) are captured.

Automated check detected the XO audit plugin is active. XO records session.signIn (session start) and session.signOut (session end) events with Unix millisecond timestamps for each user session. Session start and end times are available in the XO audit trail via the REST API. ISSO action: Query the audit API: GET /rest/v0/plugins/audit/records?limit=10 and verify records include 'time' field in Unix milliseconds. Confirm session.signIn and session.signOut pairs are present for the same userId.

Automated check could not confirm the XO audit plugin is active. Session start/end time audit records may not be generated. ISSO action: (1) Install and activate the @xen-orchestra/audit plugin; (2) Perform a login and logout; (3) Verify audit records for session.signIn and session.signOut exist with timestamps; (4) Confirm timestamps have millisecond granularity and are in UTC.

Automated check detected the XO audit plugin is active. XO audit plugin records all object access events including VM operations (start/stop/snapshot/migrate/console), host management, storage repository access, network configuration, and pool membership changes. Both successful and authorized operations are recorded. Unauthorized access attempts return errors which are logged by the application. ISSO action: Test object access logging by accessing a VM and verifying the audit record includes: userId, action, objectType (vm/host/sr/network), objectId, and timestamp.

Automated check could not confirm the XO audit plugin is active. Object access audit records may not be generated. ISSO action: (1) Install and activate the @xen-orchestra/audit plugin; (2) Access a VM (start or view console); (3) Verify audit record includes: userId, action, object type, object ID, timestamp; (4) Test unauthorized access (attempt restricted action) and verify the failed attempt is also recorded.

Xen Orchestra is a web-based virtualization management application. Users interact with XO exclusively via HTTPS web UI and REST API. XO does not expose terminal emulators, command shells, file system browsers, or direct OS command execution interfaces to authenticated users. The STIG check explicitly states this requirement is not applicable when the application does not provide direct access to the system. This condition applies to XO deployments.

Automated check detected the XO audit plugin is active and XO is not configured with LDAP enterprise authentication. XO audit plugin records user account lifecycle events: user.create, user.set (modify), and user.delete operations are captured with userId (admin performing action), target userId, action type, and timestamp. ISSO action: Test account lifecycle logging: (1) Create a test user and verify audit record; (2) Modify the user and verify; (3) Delete the user and verify. Confirm each event includes: adminUserId, targetUserId, action, and timestamp.

Automated check could not confirm the XO audit plugin is active or account lifecycle events are logged. Account lifecycle audit records may not be generated. ISSO action: (1) Install and activate the @xen-orchestra/audit plugin; (2) Create, modify, and delete a test user account; (3) Verify audit records for each lifecycle event are created; (4) Confirm records include: performing user ID, target user ID, action, and timestamp.

XO is configured to use LDAP/AD enterprise authentication. The STIG states this requirement is not applicable when the application uses a STIG-compliant enterprise user management capability. Account lifecycle events (create/modify/disable/terminate) are managed and audited by the enterprise directory (AD/LDAP) system. Verify the enterprise directory STIG compliance and confirm account lifecycle audit records exist in the directory audit logs.

Automated check confirmed the XO audit plugin is present and the XO service is active under systemd. The audit plugin is loaded with the XO application on startup. Winston logger initializes with the application and begins logging from the first event. systemd journals service start events capturing the startup sequence. ISSO action: Verify session auditing begins on startup by reviewing systemd journal entries: journalctl -u xo-server --since 'last reboot' | head -20. Confirm log entries begin immediately upon service start.

Automated check could not confirm the XO audit plugin is active or that session auditing begins on startup. ISSO action: (1) Install and activate the @xen-orchestra/audit plugin; (2) Restart the xo-server service: systemctl restart xo-server; (3) Review logs immediately after restart: journalctl -u xo-server -f; (4) Verify the first log entries appear immediately upon service start; (5) Confirm the audit plugin logs a startup event.

Automated check confirmed the XO service runs under systemd which records all service stop/shutdown events in the system journal. systemd logs both graceful shutdown (systemctl stop xo-server) and unexpected termination events with timestamps. This provides comprehensive shutdown event logging. ISSO action: Review recent shutdown events: journalctl -u xo-server | grep -i 'stop\|shut\|deactiv' | tail -10. Verify shutdown events are captured with timestamp and reason.

Automated check could not confirm systemd manages the XO service or that shutdown events are logged. ISSO action: (1) Verify xo-server runs as a systemd service: systemctl status xo-server; (2) Stop and start the service to generate shutdown events; (3) Verify: journalctl -u xo-server | grep -i stopped; (4) Confirm shutdown events include: timestamp, service name, and exit status; (5) If not systemd-managed, configure XO to log shutdown events via Winston.

Automated check detected the XO audit plugin is active and XO configuration references outbound connections to XCP-ng hosts. XO audit records include source IP (connecting client) and target object references (host IDs which map to destination IPs). Outbound connections to XCP-ng hosts via XAPI are logged per-operation in XO audit records. ISSO action: Verify destination IP logging by checking audit records for host operations: GET /rest/v0/plugins/audit/records?limit=20. Confirm records reference the destination XCP-ng host by ID (which can be resolved to IP via server list).

Automated check could not confirm the XO audit plugin is active or that destination IP addresses are logged for outbound connections. ISSO action: (1) Install and activate the @xen-orchestra/audit plugin; (2) Perform an operation on a VM hosted on a specific XCP-ng host; (3) Verify the audit record references the target host (which maps to the destination IP); (4) Check nginx access logs for upstream proxy destination logging; (5) Review syslog for outbound connection destination IPs to DNS, LDAP, and XCP-ng hosts.

XO provides audit logging of user data access operations. The XO audit plugin (@xen-orchestra/audit) is installed and records all user API operations, including read/list/get actions that constitute data access. Each audit record includes the action name (API method), userId of the authenticated user, and timestamp. All data access is performed via the XO JSON-RPC API, and the audit plugin intercepts all API calls at the middleware layer.
ISSO VERIFICATION: 1. Confirm XO audit plugin is enabled in XO web UI (Settings > Plugins > Audit) 2. Review audit records via API: GET /rest/v0/plugins/audit/records 3. Verify read-type actions (vm.list, host.get, etc.) are present in audit records 4. Confirm audit records are retained per organizational policy (minimum 1 year for DoD)

XO audit logging of user data access operations was not confirmed. The XO audit plugin may not be installed or enabled.
REMEDIATION STEPS: 1. Install XO audit plugin: In XO web UI, go to Settings > Plugins 2. Find '@xen-orchestra/audit' or 'audit' plugin and enable it 3. For XOCE: npm install @xen-orchestra/audit in the XO packages directory 4. Verify the plugin logs user data access events after enabling 5. Test by performing a data access operation and reviewing audit records
ALTERNATIVE: If using a SIEM or external logging solution that captures all XO API calls, provide documentation showing data access events are captured and attributed to users.

XO provides audit logging of user data change operations. The XO audit plugin (@xen-orchestra/audit) records all create, update, and delete API operations. Each modification action (vm.create, vm.set, vm.delete, acl.add, acl.remove, etc.) is logged with the full action name, authenticated userId, and timestamp.
ISSO VERIFICATION: 1. Confirm XO audit plugin is enabled in XO web UI (Settings > Plugins > Audit) 2. Perform a change operation (e.g., start a VM, modify a setting) 3. Verify the change appears in audit records: GET /rest/v0/plugins/audit/records 4. Confirm the record includes: action name, userId, and timestamp 5. Retain audit records per organizational policy (minimum 1 year for DoD)

XO audit logging of user data change operations was not confirmed. The XO audit plugin may not be installed or enabled.
REMEDIATION STEPS: 1. Install and enable XO audit plugin via XO web UI (Settings > Plugins) 2. For XOCE deployments: install @xen-orchestra/audit package 3. Verify change operations (create/update/delete) are captured in audit records 4. Test by creating or modifying a resource and checking audit log
If application design documents specify protected data elements, verify those specific elements' changes are also captured. Consult XO documentation for audit plugin configuration.

XO audit records include date and time stamps on all log entries. systemd journal provides precise ISO 8601 timestamps (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS+TZ) for all xo-server events as a function of the journald service. Timestamps are added at the kernel level and cannot be disabled without disabling journald.
ISSO VERIFICATION: 1. Run: journalctl -u xo-server --no-pager -n 10 --output=short-iso 2. Confirm each line has an ISO 8601 timestamp prefix 3. If using file-based logging: tail -5 /var/log/xo-server.log 4. Note: Per V-222425, timestamps should use UTC/GMT for DoD compliance (local timezone detected as non-UTC - separate finding)

Date/time stamps in XO audit records could not be confirmed by automated check. Manual verification is required.
VERIFICATION STEPS: 1. Access the system: ssh root@xo1 2. Review journal: journalctl -u xo-server --no-pager -n 20 --output=short-iso 3. Verify each audit entry has a date/time stamp 4. Review log files if file-based logging is configured
If timestamps are absent, configure application or application server to include date and time in all audit log entries.

XO audit records identify which component, feature, or function triggered each audit event. The XO audit plugin records the API action name (e.g., 'vm.create', 'acl.add', 'user.set') for each logged event. This action name identifies the specific XO component and operation that triggered the audit record. The systemd journal additionally tags all entries with _SYSTEMD_UNIT=xo-server.service as the source component.
ISSO VERIFICATION: 1. Review audit records: GET /rest/v0/plugins/audit/records?limit=10 2. Verify each record includes an 'action' field (e.g., 'vm.start', 'host.get') 3. Confirm the action name identifies the XO feature/function that triggered the event 4. Document key XO components: web server (express), API server (xo-server), database (LevelDB), session store (Redis)

XO audit records identifying the triggering component/function were not confirmed. Manual review of application documentation and logs is required.
VERIFICATION STEPS: 1. Obtain architecture documentation identifying XO components: - Web/API server: xo-server (Node.js/Express) - Data store: LevelDB at /var/lib/xo-server - Session store: Redis - Authentication: local + optional LDAP/SAML plugins 2. Access audit logs and verify component identification in entries 3. If XO audit plugin is not installed, install it to enable structured audit records with action names identifying the triggering component/function

XO is configured with centralized logging AND includes a unique application identifier in forwarded log entries. The hostname and application name (xo-server) are included in all log entries forwarded to the centralized logging solution.
ISSO VERIFICATION: 1. Verify centralized logging configuration: grep -rE '@@?' /etc/rsyslog.conf /etc/rsyslog.d/ 2. Confirm forwarded entries include hostname: check rsyslog template or default format 3. Verify application name (xo-server) is identifiable in centralized log entries 4. Test by reviewing a sample of centralized log entries for XO source identification

XO is configured with centralized logging but a unique application identifier was not confirmed in the forwarded log entries.
REMEDIATION STEPS: 1. Configure rsyslog/syslog-ng to include hostname and program name in all log entries 2. Example rsyslog template: $template CustomFormat,"%HOSTNAME% %programname% %msg% " 3. Verify xo-server is identifiable as the application in centralized log storage 4. Coordinate with SIEM team to confirm XO logs are distinguishable from other sources

This requirement is Not Applicable. XO is not configured to use a centralized logging solution. Per STIG check content: if the application logs locally and does not utilize a centralized logging solution, this requirement is Not Applicable.
XO currently logs to the local systemd journal and/or local log files only. No remote syslog, syslog-ng, or systemd-journal-upload destinations are configured.
NOTE: For DoD environments, configuring centralized audit log forwarding is strongly recommended to satisfy V-222481 (off-load audit records) and support SIEM integration. See VATES_COMPLIANCE_BLOCKERS.md for implementation guidance.

XO audit records include event outcome information. The XO audit plugin records action results, including error conditions. The systemd journal captures success/error states for xo-server operations. Successful API calls are logged by the audit plugin; errors are logged by both the audit plugin and the application-level error handlers.
ISSO VERIFICATION: 1. Review audit records for outcome fields: GET /rest/v0/plugins/audit/records 2. Check for error records: journalctl -u xo-server -n 50 | grep -i 'error\|fail' 3. Verify successful operations are also captured (implied by default per STIG) 4. Document that success events may be implied if documented as organizational baseline

Event outcome information in XO audit records was not confirmed. Manual verification of audit log format is required.
VERIFICATION STEPS: 1. Perform both a successful and a failed operation in XO 2. Review audit records and confirm both outcomes are captured 3. Verify the audit plugin records error conditions and success states
REMEDIATION: Install/enable XO audit plugin to capture structured audit records that include event outcomes. Configure application error handlers to log failure details.

XO audit records include user identity information for all events. The XO audit plugin records the authenticated userId (XO user account ID) for every API action. This userId is the primary identity associated with each audit event, establishing accountability for all privileged and non-privileged operations.
ISSO VERIFICATION: 1. Review audit records: GET /rest/v0/plugins/audit/records?limit=10 2. Verify each record includes a 'userId' field with the authenticated user's ID 3. Cross-reference userId with XO user accounts: GET /rest/v0/users 4. For LDAP/AD users, verify userId maps to the AD account identity 5. Confirm system-level processes are identified differently from user actions

User identity in XO audit records was not confirmed by automated check. Manual review is required.
VERIFICATION STEPS: 1. Log into XO as a test user and perform an action 2. Review audit records: GET /rest/v0/plugins/audit/records 3. Verify the action record includes the userId of the test account
REMEDIATION: Install/enable XO audit plugin. Without the audit plugin, XO does not produce structured per-user audit records. The audit plugin is required for DoD compliance.

XO audit records capture the full API action details for all privileged commands. XO uses a JSON-RPC API architecture where all privileged commands are API method calls (e.g., 'vm.create', 'vm.delete', 'acl.add', 'host.set'). The XO audit plugin records the complete method name (action) along with the authenticated userId for every privileged operation, fulfilling the full-text recording requirement.
ISSO VERIFICATION: 1. Perform a privileged operation (create VM, modify ACL, add user) 2. Review audit records: GET /rest/v0/plugins/audit/records 3. Verify the record includes the full action name and userId 4. Confirm privileged commands (admin operations) are distinguishable from user actions 5. For group account scenarios: verify individual userId is always recorded (no shared accounts)

Full-text recording of privileged commands in XO audit records was not confirmed. Manual verification is required.
VERIFICATION STEPS: 1. Perform privileged operations as an admin user 2. Review audit records and verify full action details are captured 3. Confirm each record includes: action name, userId, timestamp, and relevant parameters
REMEDIATION: Install/enable XO audit plugin. This is the only mechanism in XO that provides structured full-text recording of privileged API commands with user attribution.

A relational database was detected but transaction recovery logging configuration was not confirmed. Manual review of database transaction logging settings is required.
